awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Virtual Engineering for Conservation and Sustainability of Cultural Heritage
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this Early-Concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) proposed research is to significantly broaden and extend the field of computational design to new application areas involving design and sustainability of natural and man-made artifacts. This award will investigate feasibility of making dramatic technological advances in the broad area of conservation of cultural heritage using methods and techniques of computational design and simulation-based engineering, with initial emphasis on conservation and safe installation of sculptures. The research will focus on computational challenges in support of digital acquisition, analysis, planning, assessment, restoration, conservation, and installation of sculptures. While individual tasks may appear to be similar to other engineering domains, the research issues in the area of cultural heritage are particularly challenging due to uniqueness, economics, aesthetics, fragility, and complex conservation history of the artifacts. The research will investigate the implications of these constraints on computational tools required to support conservation and sustainability of cultural heritage in the next century and beyond.

If successful, the research is expected to be broadly applicable beyond sculptures and installations, leading to in situ analysis and rapid  cquisition of physics for a variety of natural and man-made structures. In addition, the immediate beneficiaries of this research include museums, conservators, sculptors, university preservation degree programs across the United States.  Strategic partnership between the University of Wisconsin and the J. Paul Getty Museum is a first step in this direction.  The successful conclusion of this EAGER award will position the researchers to address the challenging research issues pertaining to in situ analysis and rapid  cquisition of physics for natural and man-made structures, which could have tremendous societal and engineering impact.

por.por_cntn:
Over the duration of the project, the two research teams at the University of Wisconsin and Getty Museum conducted a number of experiments to determine the efficacy and limitations of computational approaches to conservation of cultural heritage artifacts.  This aim of this proposal was to investigate feasibility of making dramatic technological advances in the broad area of conservation of cultural heritage using methods and techniques of computational design and simulation-based engineering, with initial emphasis on conservation and safe installation of sculptures. Specific artifacts included ancient vase, bust, and a monumental sculpture (Mozia Charioteer) that will be brought from Sicily for a major exhibition at the Getty museum. Computational experiments have been conducted on each these artifacts in order to determine feasibility of fully automated structural analysis and in order to identify key unsolved problems in each category of artifacts.

Our initial studies confirm that computational design and manufacturing can be used to transform the restoration and installation of sculptures and public art into a precise, efficient, computationally supported science based activity, setting new standards for conservation and safety.  Digital sculpture acquisition can be achieved by several means, including rapid and approximate modeling, semi-automated reconstruction from laser scanning, and automated photogrammetry. We achieved a major goal of being able to carry out meaningful and automated analysis of the selected artifacts for general stability and initial seismic response. We also identified several challenging tasks for which current computational technology is inadequate, including simulation of complex assemblies and installations with small structural features that are common in aesthetically pleasing installation of cultural artifacts. We developed several strategies for planning, assessment, and conservation using mixture of the available computational tools, rudimentary analytical calculations, and experimental data.  

Based on our findings, we are currently working to formulate a viable strategy for further research in the areas of conservation and sustainability of cultural heritage.
